sentences: Samar Das (Bengali: সমর দাস) (10 December 1925 – 25 September 2001) was a Bangladeshi musician and composer.
In 1953, he joined HMV as a pianist in their backing orchestra.
He became chief music director in 1966 of the Cultural Academy located in Karachi, Pakistan.
Also in 1966, he led the Pakistan Delegation to the Commonwealth Music Festival in London.
In 1967, he was appointed a music director at Dhaka Radio.
He burst onto the Pakistan movie scene with his score for the first Bengali film made in Pakistan, Mukh O Mukhosh, and became famous overnight.

He was chosen to be the Music Director for the South Asian Federation Games, held in Dhaka, in both 1985 and 1995, where his orchestrations were seen and heard by an estimated audience of over 500 million across the SAARC countries during the opening and closing ceremonies.
In the year of 1987 Samar Das was appointed as chief music teacher to train up the students of Bangladesh Army Military Band in Dhaka Cantonment.
In the year of 1987 Samar Das was appointed as chief music teacher to train up the students of Bangladesh Army Military Band in Dhaka Cantonment.
Samar Das played a prominent role in the Bangladesh War of Liberation in 1971.
This version of the national anthem is still played every morning and evening on Bangladesh Television and radio.
Until a paralyzing stroke one year before his death, Samar Das was actively involved in cultural activities to highlight the Bangladesh Liberation War.

In 1985, for instance, he worked with the Muktijoddha Kalyan Trust (Freedom Fighter Benevolence Trust) to compile a collection of songs from the liberation war featuring the original singers from the Swadhin Bangla Betar Kendra, to raise funds for the families of injured freedom fighters.
